{{Wireless embedded system |brand=Netgear |model=WNR3500 |revision=v2 |series=N300 |image1=Netgear_WNR3500-01.jpg |serialnum_prefix=25V20 |asin=B001GYDJP2 |manuf_country=China |is_manuf=No |manuf=Foxconn |manuf_model=U12H127 |manuf_rev=T00 |availability=Discontinued |est_release_date=07/07/2009 |fcc_date=01/23/2009 |fcc_id=PY308400093 |ic_id=4054A-08400093 |pcb_id=U12H127T00 |type=wireless router |pwr_v=12 |pwr_amp=1.0 |pwr_conn=barrel |pwr_vac=120 |pwr_ac_hz=60 |cpu1_brand=Broadcom |cpu1_model=BCM4718A1;BCM4718A1KFBG, CS0950 P11, 950511 N1; |cpu1_cspeed=453 |fla1=4 |fla1_brand=Macronix |fla1_model=MX25L3205DMI-12G |ram1=32 |ram1_brand=Samsung |ram1_model=K4T51163QG-HCE6 |jtag=yes,, 12-pin header,, unpopulated |serial=yes,, 6-pin header,, unpopulated,, (115200,8,N,1) |wi1_chip1_brand=Broadcom |wi1_chip1_model=BCM4718A1;BCM4718A1KFBG, CS0950 P11, 950511 N1; |wi1_802dot11_protocols=bgn |wi1_txchains=2 |wi1_rxchains=2 |wi1_sstreams=2 |eth_cpu=true |sw_brand=Broadcom |sw_model=BCM53115S;BCM53115SKFBG, UG1002 P30, 954577 01A; |lan_speed=1G |lan_ports=4 |wan_speed=1G |wan_ports=1 |flags=N300, WPS |stock_boot=CFE;;(128k); |tp_firmware=FreshTomato, DD-WRT, Tomato (Shibby) |802dot11_protocols=bgn |default_ssid=NETGEAR |default_ssid_regex=^NETGEAR$ |default_ip=192.168.1.1 |default_user=admin |default_pass=password |oui=C0:3F:0E, 00:26:F2 |oui_eth=C0:3F:0E, 00:26:F2 }} {{TagLine|RangeMax Wireless-N Gigabit Router}} :{{SupportPage|vendor=NETGEAR|model=WNR3500v2|vs_id=8196}} Manuf. by [[Foxconn]] (Hon Hai) U12H127T00/U12H127T70 {{See also|Netgear WNR3500|Netgear PCB ID|Netgear}} == Models == {| style="background-color: #f8f9fa; border: 1px solid #a2a9b1; border-bottom-width: 3px; border-collapse: collapse; color: #202122; margin: 1em 0; text-align: center; vertical-align: middle;" ! U12H172T99_NETGEAR |} == Power supply == * '''''Input:''''' 120VAC 1.5A @ 60Hz (N.A.) / 230VAC 1.5A @ 50Hz (Europe, U.K.) / 240VAC 1.5A @ 50Hz (Aus.) * '''''Output:''''' 12VDC 1A == Flashing == {{Flashnotice}} === Flashing DD-WRT === * [[dd-wrt-wiki:Supported_Devices#Netgear|Supported]] {{DDWRTNotice|k26req}} # Perform a [[WikiDevi.Wi-Cat.RU:DD-WRT/Hard reset or 30/30/30|hard reset (30-30-30)]] on the device. # Configure your PC for a static/manual IP address of 192.168.1.10. # Make sure nothing else but the power cord and your PC is connected to the router. # Flash [ftp://ftp.dd-wrt.com/others/eko/V24-K26/svn18946/dd-wrt.v24-18946_NEWD-2_K2.6_mini-WNR3500v2.chk dd-wrt.v24-18946_NEWD-2_K2.6_mini-WNR3500v2.chk] to the device. # Wait five minutes. # Browse to http://192.168.1.1/ and make sure you get the Change Password page. # Perform another [[WikiDevi:DD-WRT/Hard reset or 30/30/30|hard reset (30-30-30)]]. # Browse to http://192.168.1.1/, change the username and password, and re-configure the router. === Flashing FreshTomato === * [https://wiki.freshtomato.org/doku.php/hardware_compatibility FreshTomato hardware compatibility table] note the following for this device: :''"Due to hard-coded jffs2 partition, flash size is reduced to only 3,473,408 bytes. As of v2022.5, FreshTomato MiniIPv6 builds'' (with the filename pattern freshtomato-K26-NVRAM32K_RT-MIPSR2--MiniIPv6.zip) ''are 3,467,534 bytes and is the only image type that will fit. It will likely become necessary before long to look back to older releases in FreshTomato's download archive for images that are still small enough to fit it's available space."'' == Upgrading == {{Upgrade dd-wrt}}}} == Reverting to stock firmware == : ''Adapted from NETGEAR's official documentation of the [https://kb.netgear.com/000059634/How-do-I-upload-firmware-to-my-NETGEAR-router-using-TFTP-from-the-Microsoft-Windows-Command-Prompt TFTP bootloader recovery process]'' The most robust method for replacing the stock firmware on this device in the event of a bad flash or a desire to stop using a third-party firmware is done using [[wikipedia:Trivial File Transfer Protocol|TFTP (Trivial File Transfer Protocol)]]. Since most third-party firmwares do not alter the device's bootloader, this method can often recover devices that has ceased functioning correctly or even connecting to other devices. As a failsafe, the bootloader is designed to probe its LAN Ethernet ports moments into the start of every boot cycle for the presence of a TFTP server at the IP address 192.168.1.10, and if one is found, to request its file list and download the first file it encounters with either an .img or a .chk file extension and write its contents into flash memory. Assuming you're working from a modern Windows PC, the process tends to closely resemble this: # Download [https://pjo2.github.io/tftpd64/ TFTPD64] to your computer and make sure it executes successfully, then exit it for now. # Downloads the [https://www.downloads.netgear.com/files/GDC/WNR3500V2/WNR3500v2%20Firmware%20Version%201.2.2.28%20(North%20America).zip OEM firmware] from the Netgear web site and unzip the file (either with the Windows File Manager or a utility like 7-Zip) so that the .chk file in it is in a directory by itself. # Configure your computer's network adapter with a static/manual IP address of 192.168.1.10, subnet mask of 255.255.255.0 and a default gateway of 192.168.1.1. Connect your network adapter to one of the router's LAN ports via Ethernet cable with the router powered off. # Launch TFTPD64 again and make sure the static IP address you just configured is selected in the drop-down menu labelled Server Interface. [https://github.com/PJO2/tftpd64/wiki/Tftpd64-Setup Configure the Base Directory for the server] as the directory where you extracted the .chk file containing the OEM firmware to. # Power on the router. If the process begins successfully, within a minute of being turned on the power LED with turn orange and begin blinking, signalling that the bootloader found all the conditions needed to trigger the TFTP recovery mode and has begun the process of transferring the file and flashing itself with it. This will be briefly confirmed on the Server tab of TFTPD64 when the router appears in the connection list while it's retrieving the firmware file, and thereafter in the program's Log tab. # Wait at least five minutes after the router closes the TFTP connection for the flashing process to complete and the router to reboot itself into the stock firmware; the process is complete when the Power LED has returned to steadily glowing white and the wireless network lights have turned on. # Return to your network adapter settings and remove the static/manual IP address, subnet mask and default gateway entries, returning it to the "Automatic" or DHCP configuration mode. # Open a web browser and go to the address 192.168.1.1 to begin reconfiguring your router's new firmware. === From DD-WRT === No GUI reversion possible yet, see serial recovery for reversion. === Flash partitions === 
 dev:  size     erasesize name
 mtd0: 00040000 00010000 "pmon"
 mtd1: 00750000 00010000 "linux"
 mtd2: 005dc000 00010000 "rootfs"
 mtd3: 00080000 00010000 "jffs2"
 mtd4: 00010000 00010000 "nvram"
 mtd5: 00010000 00010000 "board_data"
== Serial-JTAG Info == {{Ombox|type=notice|text='''{{Red|NOTE}}:''' This section is assuming you know how to use the [http://www.chmaas.handshake.de/delphi/freeware/xvi32/xvi32.htm XVI32 Hex Editor], [https://osdn.net/projects/zjtag/ zJTAG] and [https://pjo2.github.io/tftpd64/ TFTPD64], as well as have a [https://openwrt.org/docs/techref/hardware/port.serial.cables USB-/Serial-TTL adapter cable] and/or a [[WikiDevi:JTAG|JTAG adapter]].}} === Serial pinouts === {| | style="padding: 0.2em 0.4em; vertical-align: top;" | '''JP1''' 
 VCC 1 o
  RX 2 o
 N/C 3 o
 N/C 4 o
  TX 5 o
 GND 6 o
| style="padding: 0.2em 0.4em; vertical-align: top;" | '''J14''' 
 nTRST   1o o2	 GND
   TDI   3o o4	 GND
   TDO   5o o6	 GND
   TMS   7o o8	 GND
   TCK   9o o10	 GND
 nSRST  11o o12  N/C
|} {| | style="padding: 0.2em 0.4em; vertical-align: top;" | '''Using a [[WikiDevi.Wi-Cat.RU:JTAG/TIAO/Universal JTAG User Manual (Parallel)|Universal JTAG Adapter]]''' 
  white  1o o2	 black
    red  3o o4	 GND
   blue  5o o6	 GND
  green  7o o8	 GND
 yellow  9o o10  GND
 orange 11o o12  N/C
| style="padding: 0.2em 0.4em; vertical-align: top;" | '''Using a [[WikiDevi.Wi-Cat.RU:JTAG/TIAO/USB Multi Protocol Adapter User's Manual#20 PIN JTAG Connector|TUMPA]]''' 
        TUMPA
   N/C  1o o2  N/C
 nTRST  3o o4  GND
   TDI  5o o6  GND
   TMS  7o o8  GND
   TCK  9o o10 GND
   N/C 11o o12 GND
   TDO 13o o14 GND
 nSRST 15o o16 GND
   N/C 17o o18 GND
   N/C 19o o20 GND
|} ===== Using the TUMPA's ribbon cable ===== # Black to your choice of pins 2,4,6,8,10 on the router and your choice of pins 4,6,8,10,12,14,16,18,20 on the TUMPA for GND (ground) # White to pin 1 on the router and pin 3 on the TUMPA for the nTRST signal # Grey to pin 3 on the router and pin 5 on the TUMPA for the TDI signal # Purple to pin 7 on both devices for the TMS signal # Blue to pin 9 on both devices for the TCK signal # Green to pin 5 on the router and pin 13 on the TUMPA for the TDO signal # Yellow to pin 11 on the router and pin 15 on the TUMPA for the nSRST signal {{Serial TTL Setup WinXP}} === DD-WRT Serial Recovery === Once you're hooked up and seeing the data output into your terminal, power cycle the router and immediately start rapidly pressing Ctrl+C until it breaks the init process through to the CFE. ==== Using a Universal JTAG Adapter ==== Confirmed working with North American unit and firmware. # Power Cycle, tjtag3 -backup:cfe128 /silent /otheroptions # Power Cycle, tjtag3 -backup:nvram /silent /otheroptions # Power Cycle, tjtag3 -backup:wholeflash /silent /otheroptions # Power Cycle, tjtag3 -backup:custom /window:0x1fc00000 /start:0x1c3e0000 /length:0x10000 /silent /otheroptions # The last step will backup the board data to "custom.bin, Using a Hex editer, check to make sure all the data looks similar to [http://www.dd-wrt.com/phpBB2/download.php?id=21561 board_data.bin] or post it to your thread in the dd-wrt forums and somebody can check it for you. # If it is similar, change "U12H127T70_NETGEAR" to "U12H127T00_NETGEAR". The mac address starts at Hex address 40 in the middle pane, make sure it's correct. The Serial number starts at Dec address 76 in the right pane, make sure it's correct. The Security Pin starts at Dec address 108 in the right pane, make sure it's correct. The actual board data starts at Dec address 256 in the right pane, make sure it matches [http://www.dd-wrt.com/phpBB2/download.php?id=21561 board_data.bin]. If it looks all messed up then start fresh with [http://www.dd-wrt.com/phpBB2/download.php?id=21561 board_data.bin] and make all the changes to it. When done "save as" "custom.bin" without the quotes. Makes sure it's in the same folder as TJTAG. # Now do the same with the cfe128, mac sure mac address match(although not as important with the cfe). Check to see if is similar to [http://www.dd-wrt.com/phpBB2/download.php?id=21562 cfe128.bin]. If not or it's just totally messed up use the reference [http://www.dd-wrt.com/phpBB2/download.php?id=21562 cfe128.bin]. Just edit it to match the information from your router. # Power Cycle, tjtag3 -flash:custom /window:0x1fc00000 /start:0x1ffe0000 /length:0x10000 /swap_endian /byte_mode /silent /otheroptions # Power Cycle, tjtag3 -flash:cfe128 /swap_endian /byte_mode /silent /otheroptions # Have TFTP.exe ready in WindowsXP, with [http://www.dd-wrt.com/phpBB2/download.php?id=21550 WNR3500v2-V1.2.2.28_25.0.85NA.chk] from that zip file. Configure your computer with a static IP address of 192.168.1.10. Connect the router to the PC via network cable. Power on the router and when it signals a connection, click Upgrade. == USB == This device has no USB ports. == VLANs == === DD-WRT VLAN Configuration === * [[WikiDevi:DD-WRT/VLAN Support]] Testing Needed == Notes == === Identifying your router's model number === {{Netgear WNR3500 Comparison Chart}} == Images == Netgear_WNR3500-01.jpg Netgear_WNR3500_b.jpg [[Has images::retail| ]]

Netgear_WNR3500L_FCC1a.jpg Netgear_WNR3500L_FCC1b.jpg Netgear_WNR3500L_FCC1c.jpg Netgear_WNR3500L_FCC1d.jpg Netgear_WNR3500L_FCC1e.jpg Netgear_WNR3500L_FCC1f.jpg Netgear_WNR3500L_FCC1g.jpg Netgear_WNR3500L_FCC1h.jpg Netgear_WNR3500L_FCC1i.jpg Netgear_WNR3500L_FCC1j.jpg Netgear_WNR3500L_FCC1k.jpg Netgear_WNR3500L_FCC1l.jpg Netgear_WNR3500L_FCC1m.jpg Netgear_WNR3500L_FCC1n.jpg Netgear_WNR3500L_FCC1o.jpg Netgear_WNR3500L_FCC1p.jpg Netgear_WNR3500L_FCC1q.jpg Netgear_WNR3500L_FCC1r.jpg Netgear_WNR3500L_FCC1s.jpg Netgear_WNR3500L_FCC1t.jpg Netgear_WNR3500L_FCC1u.jpg Netgear_WNR3500L_FCC1v.jpg Netgear_WNR3500L_FCC1w.jpg Netgear_WNR3500L_FCC1x.jpg Netgear_WNR3500L_FCC1y.jpg Netgear_WNR3500L_FCC1z.jpg Netgear_WNR3500L_FCC2a.jpg [[Has images::fcc| ]] == See also == * [[Netgear WNR3500v1]] * [[Netgear WNR3500Lv1]] * [[Netgear WNR3500Lv2]] == External links == === DD-WRT Forum === * [https://forum.dd-wrt.com/phpBB2/viewtopic.php?t=149475 Netgear WNR3500 v2.0 Brick (solved)] * [https://forum.dd-wrt.com/phpBB2/viewtopic.php?t=143960 Netgear WNR3500 v2.0] * [https://forum.dd-wrt.com/phpBB2/viewtopic.php?t=57189 DD-WRT for Netgear WNR3500v2?] * [https://forum.dd-wrt.com/phpBB2/viewtopic.php?t=75647 Netgear WNR3500V2 - rollback to original FW] * [https://forum.dd-wrt.com/phpBB2/viewtopic.php?p=523816 Netgear 3500 v2 died after firmware upgrade] * [https://forum.dd-wrt.com/phpBB2/viewtopic.php?t=72788 WNR3500v2 stuck in waiting for tftp mode [Solved]] __NOTOC__
